premises: If a diet is high in fiber, then it helps with digestion
A diet is high in fiber
incorrect conclusions: It does not help with digestion
It helping with digestion implies that a diet is high in fiber
It not helping with digestion implies that a diet is high in fiber
A diet not being high in fiber implies that it does not help with digestion

premises: If a person consumes more calories than they burn, then they gain weight
A person consumes more calories than they burn
incorrect conclusions: Gaining weight implies that a person consumes more calories than they burn
Not gaining weight implies that a person consumes more calories than they burn
A person not consuming more calories than they burn implies that they do not gain weight

premises: If a food is rich in antioxidants, then it promotes health
A food is rich in antioxidants
incorrect conclusions: It promoting health implies that a food is rich in antioxidants
It not promoting health implies that a food is rich in antioxidants
A food not being rich in antioxidants implies that it does not promote health
